Synopsis:
The third and final part of the Apu trilogy. Apu is now an adult seeking his fortune in the world and is an aspiring writer. One day, accompanying a friend to a wedding, Apu lands up marrying Aparna. Apu's happiness in finding his aoul mate is shortlived however, as Aparna dies at childbirth, leaving a son Kajol behind. A devastated Apu, leaves Kajol with his grandparents and goes travelling. Much later, he returns in his reunion with Kajol, both father and son find a meaning in life again..

Comments:
For me Apur Sansar has always been the favourite in the Trilogy. It is a more mature Ray than in Pather Panchali, the screenplay is much more complex with nuances that delight you when you think about them and Subrata Mitra's camera work is par excellence. This was also the last Ray film in which the music director is not Ray himself (Ravi Shankar). Shankar's musical genius is in full display in a restrained musical score that is in keeping with the earlier films of the Trilogy, lending a harmony that adds to the cinematic genius of Ray.
